inbodydescription.para: Throughout this code seawater is taken to contain no dissolved air.

sect2.title: Finding func0
sect2.para: When func0 is zero or positive we can immediately calculate the three outputs, as the bulk enthalpy, h_bulk, is too large to allow any ice at thermodynamic equilibrium. The result will be (warm) seawater with no frazil ice being present. The three outputs can be set and the rest

sect2.title: of this code does not need to be performed.
sect2.para: Begin to find the solution for those data points that have func0 < 0, implying that the output will be a positive ice mass fraction w_Ih_final. Do a quasi-Newton step with a separate polynomial estimate of the derivative of func with respect to the ice mass fraction. This section of the code delivers initial values of both w_Ih and SA to the rest of the more formal modified Newtons Method approach of

sect2.title: McDougall and Wotherspoon (2014).
sect2.para: Calculating the estimate of the derivative of func, dfunc_dw_Ih, to be

sect2.title: fed into the iterative Newton s Method.
sect2.para: Enter the main McDougall-Wotherspoon (2014) modified Newton-Raphson

sect2.title: loop
sect2.para: on the first iteration these values are already known
This ensures that the mass fraction of ice never exceeds 0.9
This ensures that the mass fraction of ice never exceeds 0.9
for
This will only trap cases that are smaller than zero by just machine precision

Finding func0. This is the value of the function, func, that would

sect2.title: result in the output w_Ih_final being exactly zero.
Setting the three outputs for data points that have func0 non-negative
sect2.para: When func0 is zero or positive then the final answer will contain no frazil ice; that is, it will be pure seawater that is warmer than the freezing temperature. If func0 >= 0 we do not need to go through the modified Newton-Raphson procedure and we can simply write down the answer, as in the following 4 lines of code.
Begin finding the solution for data points that have func0 < 0, so that

sect2.title: the output will have a positive ice mass fraction w_Ih_final.

The ice mass fraction out of this code is restricted to be less than 0.9.

memberdef.argsstring: (double sa, double ct, double p, double w_seaice, double sa_seaice, double t_seaice, double *sa_final, double *ct_final)
memberdef.name: gsw_melting_seaice_into_seawater

inbodydescription.para: The seawater ct input is below the freezing temp

The 1e-6 C buffer in the allowable t_seaice is to ensure that there is some ice Ih in the sea ice. Without this buffer, that is if t_seaice is allowed to be exactly equal to tf_sa_seaice, the seaice is actually 100% brine at Absolute Salinity of SA_seaice.

ctf = gsw_ct_freezing(sa_final,p,saturation_fraction) if (h_final .lt. gsw_enthalpy_ct_exact(sa_final,ctf,p)) then Melting this much seaice is not possible as it would result in frozen seawater sa_final = gsw_error_code(4,func_name) ct_final = sa_final return end if

inbodydescription.para: for GSW_TEOS10_CONSTANTS use gtc
for GSW_TEOS10_CONSTANTS use gtc
initial estimate of the potential enthalpy.
The error of this fit ranges between -6e-3 and 6e-3 J/kg over the potential temperature range of -100 to 2 deg C, or the potential enthalpy range of -5.7 x 10^5 to -3.3 x 10^5 J/kg.
for GSW_TEOS10_CONSTANTS use gtc
rec_Pa2dbar is to have dCTf_dp in units of K/dbar rather than K/Pa Find CT > CT_freezing_p0. If this is the case, the input CT value represent seawater that will not be frozen at any positive p.
Find CT < CT_freezing_p10000. If this is the case, the input CT value represent seawater that is frozen even at p = 10,000 dbar.
This is the initial (linear) guess of the freezing pressure, in dbar.
this dctf_dp is the initial value of the partial derivative of ct_freezing with respect to pressure (in dbar) at fixed sa, assuming that the saturation_fraction is zero.
For input potential enthalpies greater than -5.1e-5, the above part of the code gives the output potential temperature of ice accurate to 1e-13 degrees C.
The variable "df_dt" below is the derivative of the above polynomial with respect to pot_enthalpy_ice. This is the initial value of the derivative of the method f.
For pot_enthalpy_ice < -5.1e5 (or pt0_ice less than about -100 deg c) these temperatures are less than those found in nature on planet earth
the heat capacity, cp, is evaluated at 0.02 c greater than usual in order to avoid stability issues and to ensure convergence near zero absolute temperature.
note the extra 0.02 c here as well

The potential temerature has a maximum error as listed in the table below.
potential temerature error (deg C)
@ potential temerature (deg C)
0.012
-273.15 to -273.12
4 x 10^-4
-232.12 to -273.0
2.5 x 10^-6
-273
7 x 10^-9
-272
3.7 x 10^-10
-270
6 x 10^-11
-268
2.5 x 10^11
-266
3 x 10^-12
-260
7 x 10^-13
-250
2.2 x 10^-13
-220
1.7 x 10^-13
>= -160
Note. The above errors in each temperature range are machine precisions for this calculation.
The error of this fit ranges between -5e-5 and 2e-4 deg C over the potential temperature range of -100 to 2 deg C, or the potential enthalpy range of -5.7 x 10^5 to -3.3 x 10^5 J/kg.
for GSW_TEOS10_CONSTANTS use gtc
This is the starting polynomial for pt of ice Ih.
we add 0.05 to the initial estimate of pt_ice at temps less than -273 to ensure that it is never less than -273.15.
we add 0.01 to the initial estimate of pt_ice used in the derivative to ensure that it is never less than -273.15 because the derivative approaches zero at absolute zero.

For temperatures less than -273.1 degsC the maximum error is less than 2x10^-7 degsC. For temperatures between -273.1 and 273 the maximum error is less than 8x10^-8 degsC, and for temperatures greater than -273 degsC the maximum error is 1.5x10^-12 degsC. These errors are over the whole ocean depths with both p and pref varying independently between 0 and 10,000 dbar, while the in-situ temperature varied independently between -273.15 and +2 degsC.
for GSW_TEOS10_CONSTANTS use gtc
h00 = gsw_enthalpy_ice(-gtc.gsw_t0,0)
for GSW_TEOS10_CONSTANTS use gtc
A very rough estimate of sa to get the saturated ct
CTsat is the estimated value of CT if the seawater were saturated with dissolved air, recognizing that it actually has the air fraction saturation_fraction; see McDougall, Barker and Feistel, 2014).
This is the band of sa within +- 2.5 g/kg of sa = 0, which we treat differently in calculating the initial values of both SA and dCT_dSA.
Find CT > CT_freezing_zero_SA. If this is the case, the input values represent seawater that is not frozen (for any positive SA).
Form the first estimate of SA from a polynomial in CT and p
Form the first estimate of CTfreezing_SA, the derivative of CT_freezing with respect to SA at fixed p.
For -SA_cut_off < SA < SA_cut_off, replace the above estimate of SA with one based on (CT_freezing_zero_SA - CT).
Begin the modified Newton-Raphson method to solve

sect2.title: f = (CT_freezing - CT) = 0 for SA.

inbodydescription.para: This is the band of sa within +- 2.5 g/kg of sa = 0, which we treat differently in calculating the initial values of both SA and dCT_dSA.
Find CT > CT_freezing_zero_SA. If this is the case, the input values represent seawater that is not frozen (at any positive SA).
Form the first estimate of SA from a polynomial in CT and p
Form the first estimate of dCT_dSA, the derivative of CT with respect to SA at fixed p.
For -SA_cut_off < SA < SA_cut_off, replace the above estimate of SA with one based on (CT_freezing_zero_SA - CT).
Begin the modified Newton-Raphson method to solve the root of

sect2.title: CT_freezing = CT for SA.

inbodydescription.para: This is the band of sa within +- 2.5 g/kg of sa = 0, which we treat differently in calculating the initial values of both SA and dCT_dSA.
Find t > t_freezing_zero_SA. If this is the case, the input values represent seawater that is not frozen (at any positive SA).
This is the inital guess of SA using a purpose-built polynomial in CT and p
Form the first estimate of tfreezing_SA, the derivative of CT_freezing with respect to SA at fixed p.
For -SA_cut_off < SA < SA_cut_off, replace the above estimate of SA with one based on (t_freezing_zero_SA - t).
Begin the modified Newton-Raphson method to find the root of

sect2.title: f = (t_freezing - t) = 0 for SA.

inbodydescription.para: This is the band of sa within +- 2.5 g/kg of sa = 0, which we treat differently in calculating the initial values of both SA and dCT_dSA.
Find t > t_freezing_zero_SA. If this is the case, the input values represent seawater that is not frozen (at any positive SA).
This is the inital guess of SA using a purpose-built polynomial in CT and p
Form the first estimate of dt_dSA, the derivative of t with respect to SA at fixed p.
For -SA_cut_off < SA < SA_cut_off, replace the above estimate of SA with one based on (t_freezing_zero_SA - t).
Begin the modified Newton-Raphson method to find the root of

sect2.title: t_freezing = t for SA.

memberdef.argsstring: (double sa, double ct, double p, double sa_seaice, double t_seaice, double *sa_freeze, double *ct_freeze, double *w_seaice)
memberdef.name: gsw_seaice_fraction_to_freeze_seawater

inbodydescription.para: The seawater ct input is below the freezing temp

The 1e-6 C buffer in the allowable t_seaice is to ensure that there is some ice Ih in the sea ice. Without this buffer, that is if t_seaice is allowed to be exactly equal to tf_sa_seaice, the sea ice is actually 100% brine at Absolute Salinity of SA_seaice.
initial guess of saf

After these 4 iterations of this modified Newton-Raphson method, the errors in SA_freeze is less than 1.5x10^-12 g/kg, in CT_freeze is less than 2x10^-13 deg C and in w_seaice is less than 2.8x10^-13 which represent machine precision for these calculations.
for GSW_TEOS10_CONSTANTS use gtc
This is the starting polynomial for pt0 of ice Ih.
we add 0.05d0 to the initial estimate of pt0_ice at temps less than -273 to ensure that it is never less than -273.15.
add 0.01d0 to the initial estimate of pt_ice used in the derivative to ensure that it is never less than -273.15d0 because the derivative approaches zero at absolute zero.

add 0.01d0 to the estimate of ptm_ice for temperatures less than -273 to ensure that they are never less than -273.15d0 because the derivative approaches zero at absolute zero and the addition of 0.01d0 degrees c ensures that when we divide by the derivatve in the modified newton routine the method does not blow up.

For temperatures less than -273.1 degsC the maximum error is less than 2x10^-7 degsC. For temperatures between -273.1 and 273 the maximum error is less than 8x10^-8 degsC, and for temperatures greater than -273 degsC the maximum error is 1.5x10^-12 degsC. These errors are over the whole ocean depths with p varying between 0 and 10,000 dbar, while the in-situ temperature varied independently between -273.15 and +2 degsC.
for GSW_TEOS10_CONSTANTS use gtc
The initial value of t_freezing_exact (for air-free seawater)
df_dt here is the initial value of the derivative of the function f whose zero (f = 0) we are finding (see Eqn. (3.33.2) of IOC et al (2010)).
Adjust for the effects of dissolved air

sect2.title: Begin the modified Newton-Raphson iterative procedure
